caption: Absolutely best sushi of my life. A must do in Chicago

Omg! Super fresh ingredients, and very tasty. We enjoyed every single course. It was such a great experience! However, the chef did not cut the fish in front of us like other omakase restaurants. But still, the fish and shrimp were so delicious! We enjoyed it so much!
Amazingly fresh sushi. The most Covid safe indoor dining possible.
The uni box did not disappoint! 👍👍👍
Wonderful pace and presentation for an Omakase.

I never write restaurant reviews but this place is so good I had to write one for them. The sushi here is second to none, they have perfected the rolls they offer. The miso soup was some of the best I've ever had. The man who served me was attentive and friendly without being annoying. With so many restaurants in Chicago closing permanently due to the financial strain caused by the governor's executive orders it would make me very sad to see this one go too.

Ordered take out for the first time from a Michelin star restaurant. Everything taste great! The reason for not giving a five star is because I think they should use a better to-go box instead of plastic.
pork spare ribs and steamed chicken potstickers. OMG! The amount of food is ample and the flavors are awesome.

Delightful in every way. Very inviting quiet restaurant for serious food but in no way stuffy. The progression of dishes is outstanding and the presentation of each course is sublime. Small but outstanding champagne, wine and sake list. Really outstanding omakase - understated but profound

With initial good press being reinforced with a Michelin star, Omakase Yume has been on our 2020 must visit restaurants. We finally made it after the restaurant indoor dining reopening.  Wow did it meet our expectations. The fish was amazing, each bite a wonderful balance of flavors - if forced to pick favorites would be a tie between Sea Bass and the Chutoro but each bite was truly special. The non-nigiri dishes were also fantastic: amazingly delicate miso soup, delicious black cod and and fabulous panna cotta to wrap it up. We added Aji (chef’s recommendation) and Wagyu (because...Wagyu) to the tasting menu and would recommend both. Didn’t try it but saw an order of the foie gras plated and were immediately envious!  The experience is faster than originally envisioned. Tough to give the full artistry and adhere to the 90 minute regulation. They did an excellent job balancing speed with presentation - only miss out on watching exquisite knife work.  We will definitely go back!
This was my first Omakase experience ever, and Yume has set a really high bar for me. The course, service, and ambience were all near perfection.
I was pleased to have enjoyed such a wonderful omakase in Chicago. Would visit again.

Way too fast tempo. I noticed a table came in late so the chef just jammed three pieces at one time as they just arrived. Presliced fish for kicking you out faster. Overcooked wagyu. Ebi was torched, and once I had a taste I knew it’s not that fresh anymore. Chef does not tell you where his fish come from and how they lived their fish lives before. Mediocre omakase for a city that doesn’t really have omakase choices!  Pros: Is omakase. Some interesting combinations such as sesame oil on kanpachi (but nothing stands out really). Chef gives me a lot of ginger
Delightful experience and truly amazing food!
I ordered a takeout and everything was delicious!
Every dish was perfect. Literally can't say enough about this place. Easily one of the top 5 omakase sushi restaurants in town.

The best take out experience during the Covid close down. Don’t be fooled with the single item option on a menu- you will have a chance to experience the fresh and well paired seafood options in one bowl. Miso would was fantastic as well. Highly recommended.
Nice chirashi bowl, as good as it gets during quarantine.

UPDATE: what the restaurant replied here does not match what the receptionist was insisting when we called. We indicated that one of us were not feeling well and the person making reservation ONE MONTH agao, only got a reminder text 1.5 hour before the cancellation deadline but was only able to call after busy workday, thus missing an hour into the 48 hour policy. All they said was we can't give exception to everyone because already many people are cancelling. And they were like: "If you can't make it because of unexpected situation, it is *YOUR RESPONSIBILITY* to find other customers to come and dine in instead." This is ridiculous and reflects poorly on the core value of this restaurants and how they treat their customers.  So OMAKSA YUME, either you do what you claim in your reply below consistently or you ADMIT that there is a mistake when you handled our call.  As a responsible person, let me give you some suggestions: 1. Have a better understanding that people have job and they don't work like restaurants hours where you can check text every minute during a work day. 2. Go have your reservation app send out reminder texts at least one day ahead of your deadline like all other restaurant does, and then you have a better ground to ask people to "notify" you as soon as possible when their plans change. 3. When you have chance to provide good customer service, DO IT RIGHT THEN, don't come back and try to sugar coat with lies to fix the situation because you are worried that an angry review might make you look bad.  ORIGINAL REVIEW: Had a reservation made 1 month ago and we wanted to cancel our reservation due to the current pandemic situation. But they insist on charging the cancellation fee even though it has only been 1 hour into the 48 hour policy. Things move so rapidly recently, and many people are gett anxious, even banks are giving grace periods to loans and stuf.. But it seems like all this business cared about, is getting their money. They were like "we can not give exception to everyone", well what kind of exception have you given then? For the short term, yes it will let you make that free money but you are losing many long term businesses. Shame on this business and the owner. I wish you guys go out of business soon and more local and smaller business can get your customers eventually.
Best sushi experience I've had in the US.
Hands down the best sushi place in Chicago. It's expensive, but it's worth every single bite. I eagerly await the next time I get to enjoy this magnificent restaurant

Overall, it was very good, but the only thing that was memorable was the matcha panna cotta for dessert. Most of the fish is already precut and the pieces are pretty small so you have to savor each bite. The rice is okay. I wanted to ask for a little more wasabi on my pieces, but it felt awkward to ask since preparation/making the sushi felt like mass producing for everyone at once rather than an individual piece catered to you. Overall, I think it's worth trying at least once, but I'd rather go to other omakases.

Overall good experience and pieces served were good. The menu currently consists mainly of fish nigiris (and in my opinion too many white fish nigiris), at this price point it would make sense to incorporate some more interesting or rare ingredients.
Excellent quality seasonal fish and expert preparations in an unassuming locale. Highly reccomend.
Fresh and good quality fish but not worth the price I think, still an experience though. Portion is very small.
Excellent quality food.  Great experience
What a delightful experience !! Highly recommended. I felt being privileged to enjoy all the delicacy.
The best sushi I have had in Chicago by a good 2 or 3 pond skips.
(Translated by Google) Best omakase in Chicago.  (Original) Best omakase in Chicago.

High-quality, well-procured fish. Great attention to the rice. Balanced fish-to-rice ratio. Intimate, zen-like space. Absolutely lovely people. And the best part for us? It’s within walking distance of our home.
I hate it
Husband wanted to go back means “great food”. Every piece was delicious. Added porgy to omakase.
Fantastic in every way!

Great presentation and food. Wonderful meal. Intimate setting. Bit pricey but worth doing once. Service was wonderful. We were told that it was BYOB, however, were surprised with a $40 corkage fee per bottle on arrival. Would've been nice to know in advance.

What an amazing experience!! Each course was the pure essence of Chef San Tae Park's brilliant imagination for sushi. Such clean and savory flavors and textures of sushi paired with wonderfully clean and fruity saki pairings made this experience totally memorable. I would highly recommend adding Omakase Yume to your foodie bucket list!!!
It's good. It's better than Raisu. Wine list is excellent. But I miss Katsu.

Great experience and excellent sushi. It’s a small spot with 8 seats so you can watch the chef prepare all the food. The sushi itself was incredible- amazing flavors and fresh. The service is also really great.

Chef Park imports fish and ingredients of the highest quality from Japan and creates an Omakase menu that is an absolute masterpiece. By far the best, most original sushi experience in Chicago. Upon entering the restaurant you are immediately teleported to Tokyo. My wife and I celebrated our honeymoon in Japan and Omakase Yume brought many delightful nostalgic memories back with each bite.
Fantastic!
The Wagyu Sashimi and Uni Sashimi were unparalleled.
The sushi was outstanding and the atmosphere was amazing as well. (pro tip, use the restroom!)
Very good quality sushi and excellent service. However, I left hungry even after ordering 4 additional items from their separate menu. At this price point, one expects to be at least satiated.
Very well paced meal with incredible flavours and a great progression. The atmosphere was very clean-lined and elegant as well, without being too much.

The food was utterly delicious - you'll have a hard time finding better sushi anywhere. I particularly loved three successive pieces of tuna - regular, medium fatty and very fatty. And the amberjack was a standout. It's a very small space and the service is excellent. However there is no magic in the ambiance or the presentation - it's neat and plain. You may not feel stuffed, but you will feel satisfied.

Have been to many omakase and sushi restaurants in NYC (where I live) and Chicago and this is by far one of the best. While you have some staples like the sake (salmon) and tuna 3 ways, all of which are amazing, you can tell that the Chef is constantly trying to innovate and try new things with the rest of the menu. They also always have seasonal and rare fish in the Specials section which you can order a la carte as add-ons. We came here for my boyfriend's birthday and they were so kind and genuine, making it truly special. My favorites were the tuna 3 ways, the salmon, the kanpachi, the wagyu (special), and the miso cod, but everything was amazing. Will definitely be coming back soon.  PSA: they have a liquor license now, so is no longer BYOB
It's great.   My third time here,  and it keeps getting better.   The Sake in particular stood out,  along with as always the Wagyu and the Otoro.  In my opinion, better than Takeya and Kyoten.
One of the best Omakase in Chicago

Had a death in the family and couldn't make reservations. Hostess was extremely rude when I called to cancel. Just because they are Michelin star doesn't mean they can treat people like they are nothing.
For all the hype we found the sushi to be average. Very overpriced for what was served.  We expect so much more.
Very good and BYO. Pricey but definitely worth the experience if you can't fly to Japan for it!
Make reservations and go ASAP! The experience was mind blowing and the chef does an amazing job with all the courses! We added extra the Waygu, Foie Gras which was well worth it.
Pros: probably the best omakase place in Chicago Cons: still doesn't justify the price. I could get better quality omakase cheaper in NYC. (yeah Chicago sucks)

Absolutely authentic with a unique twist from the chef. Every bit was perfectly seasoned and of the best quality. It’s easy to forget you’re in Chicago dining here. Fish is almost equivalent to that if the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo. To top it off they’re BYOB! Chef gives extra props to you if you bring a great bottle of sake 😉

Absolutely amazing! I’ve been fortunate to have some amazing sushi in Tokyo before, and this place absolutely ranks up there! Chef Park is an absolute master of his craft. Every piece was fantastic and delicious. The space is lovely and quite intimate. Just eight seats around the sushi bar. Can’t wait to go back!

I dinned here last night and found out about this place through Eater. This is a very unique omakase restaurant that has only 8 counter seats in the entire place.  For the food, everything was exceptional. We added on a few specials including the Uni, Ikura, Foie Gras,  Wagyu, and Hotaru Ika. The Uni and Wagyu were my favorite specials out of the ones that we decided to try. As far as the omakase that is included in the $125 my favorite bites were the Akami, Otoro, and Sake but everything overall was delicious and the presentation of the fish was nice.  There is something that this place lacked and it was warmth. The entire meal is very quiet. I think it would be helpful if the chef introduced himself and asked the customers if this was their first time dining at Omakase Yume. I think this would help make it feel like a more welcoming environment. Some soft music in the background might be helpful too.  All in with tip, specials, and omakase we were in about $600 for the two of us. I think with that price some of the specials should be included in the $125/omakase.

(Translated by Google) Senior sushi dishes, per capita more than 150 US dollars, the price is not high. The chef is a Korean sushi chef and I feel that the food is not so good.  (Original) 高级寿司料理，人均150美元以上，性价比不高。主厨是一个韩国寿司师傅，感觉料理没有那么好
Awesome experience. Talking to the chef was very fun and the whole is experience is very intimate. Highly recommend if you like sushi!

This is a Korean Omakase. Not a japanese omakase. The flavours here are sometimes stronger and different from the usual brushing of soy on a japanese nigiri. Sometimes, the fish is also left to age for a few days. I can see how this approach might upset the 1-star reviewer who may not be used to stronger fish flavours. I appreciated Chef Park's silence. The dessert was smooth, light, and not overly rich.  The sweet shrimp was sublime.

Yep. Believe the hype. This meal experience was delicious and one of a kind. The low-key setting and ability to watch as Chef Park prepares each course in relative silence creates a relaxing atmosphere that allows you to savor each lovingly prepared delicious bite. We added the uni and an in-season sardine to the tasting menu and both were sublime. For now it's BYOB, and the whole foods down the street has suitable sake. Highly recommended.
Beautiful presentation, beyond delicious! Definitely well worth for the experience! Would love to go again!!
Fantastic experience. Sushi was amazing
Excellent Sushi.. great experience.

I recently came here with a friend and I can confidently say that it was one of the best experiece we ever had. First off, the atmosphere was very welcoming. The chef was mostly focused on making sushi but he kindly answered any questions we had about the food such as the origin of the fish and the techniques he was applying to the dish. The hosts were amazing! They were all attentative and quick to answer any of our concerns. In fact, my table next to me brought two different types of sake and the host was able to recommend one of them for better harmony with the upcoming dishes. The hosts were very respectful and refilled our drinks throughout the course meal. We would occasionally make little talks with them and we could tell they were knowledgeable about the sushis.  As for the food, it was absolutely amazing.  As a person who visits Korea and Japan yearly, I must say the sushis here are top notch. I could tell all the fishes were extremly fresh. In fact, I did not expect to find high quality fishes such as kinmedai. The sake, chutoro, and kanpachi was exceptionally good! Chutoro had just the rght amount of fat which enhanced the flavor of the tuna and its unique texture when biting into it.  Ive been to many japaneses restuarants around the city and I must say this place is the best in Chicago. You could tell the chef truly creates authentic japanese cruisine. When you eat the sushi, it is a bit warm due to the fresh made rice but that is how sushi actually should be. The sushis from some other resturants come out cold and you could tell that the sushis were pre-made. I hoenstly did not expect the sushis here to taste so similar to the ones in Korea/Japan with its taste, freshness, texture, and even the atmosphere. If you want to try authentic sushi as if you're in East Asia, I would 100% recommend this place.  p.s. Get the wagyu sushi when its time for special order. It will blow your tastebuds.

I really wanted to like this place.  I have wished Chicago got a restaurant dedicated to omakase.  Sadly this one was a huge let-down.  I had a few issues but bottom line the fish at such a dinner needs to be the freshest possible.  At my dinner *all* the fish tasted fishy and not in a good way.  It was warm and flaccid like it had been sitting in a warm kitchen for too long.  Imagine you let fresh cut fish sit on your kitchen counter for a few hours...it was like that and really unpleasant.  At these prices one expects nothing less than perfection.  This was not even close.

The chef is originally from Izakaya Yume, which is located in Niles. He's been in the sushi world for quite a while. I've never paid much attention to him until he opened up in Niles. I tried it out and was a fan, when I heard he opened up an 8 seat omakase restaurant, I wanted to see how it'd be. To my surprise, it was delightfully a lot better than I had hoped for. The fish were fresh, you can tell by how tight the meat was. Everything was very flavorful, I can't say that anything was bad. Only two things didn't jump out at me and that's just me though: Miso Soup (for obvious reasons) and the Ika (squid). I'm not saying the Ika was bad, just saying it could've been enhanced with some other flavorings. I'd give this place a try before it gets overly popular and you're waiting weeks out before getting a reservation. They've been open for barely 10 days and I had to make a reservation 2 weeks out already.
